calculos_que_son: âš ï¸ What are kidney stones in cats?
calculos_que_son_desc:
Kidney stones, or renal calculi, are solid accumulations of minerals that can form in the kidneys or urinary tract. In cats, 98% of these stones are composed of calcium oxalate.

Types of calcium oxalate stones:

â€¢ Monohydrate: Related to excess oxalate in urine (hyperoxaluria).
â€¢ Dihydrate: Associated with high calcium levels in urine (hypercalciuria).

In cats, nearly all stones are of the monohydrate type, suggesting that excess oxalate is the main cause.
calculos_formacion_desc:
Main causes:

â€¢ Diet: Exclusive dry food or diets that overly acidify urine.
â€¢ Metabolic factors: High calcium or oxalate levels.
â€¢ Genetics: Some breeds are more predisposed.
â€¢ Urinary tract infections.
calculos_riesgo_desc:
â€¢ Exclusive dry food: Reduces water intake and concentrates urine.
â€¢ Neutered male: Higher risk of obstructions due to narrower urethra.
â€¢ Predisposed breeds: Persians, Himalayans, Birmans, Ragdolls, American Shorthairs, and Scottish Folds.
â€¢ Metabolic problems: Hypercalcemia and hyperoxaluria.
calculos_signos: How do I know if my cat has stones?
calculos_signos_desc:
Warning signs:

â€¢ Difficulty or pain when urinating.
â€¢ Blood in urine.
â€¢ Excessive genital licking.
â€¢ Loss of appetite or lethargy.
â€¢ Abdominal inflammation.

Important: If you notice these signs, go to the vet immediately.
calculos_prevencion: Prevention based on the catâ€™s life stage
calculos_prevencion_desc:
Kittens (up to 1 year):
â€¢ Proper diet: Moist foods rich in nutrients.
â€¢ Hydration: Constant access to fresh water.
â€¢ Regular check-ups: Detect issues early.

Adult cats (1â€“7 years):
â€¢ Combine dry and wet food: Promotes hydration.
â€¢ Neutered cat diets: Manage weight and lower urinary risks.

Senior cats (>7 years):
â€¢ Renal-support diet: Eases kidney workload.
â€¢ Health monitoring: Frequent check-ups to assess renal and urinary function.
dentales_que_son: âš ï¸ What are dental diseases in cats?
dentales_que_son_desc: Dental diseases are extremely common in cats, but they often go unnoticed until pain or health problems become severe. The accumulation of plaque and tartar can lead to infections, tooth loss, and even affect internal organs if not treated in time.
dentales_periodontal_desc: It is a progressive inflammation of the gums and supporting tooth structures due to plaque and tartar buildup. If untreated, it can cause serious infections, tooth loss, and even affect organs like the heart, kidneys, and liver.
dentales_etapas_desc:
1ï¸âƒ£ Gingivitis (Stage 1 - Reversible): Inflammation of the gums without bone loss. Symptoms: Red gums, mild bad breath.

2ï¸âƒ£ Early Periodontitis (Stage 2): Severe inflammation with early tissue damage. Symptoms: Moderate bad breath, bleeding gums when eating or touching the mouth.

3ï¸âƒ£ Moderate Periodontitis (Stage 3): Evident bone loss and periodontal pockets. Symptoms: Pain, drooling, tooth loss, trouble eating.

4ï¸âƒ£ Severe Periodontitis (Stage 4 - Irreversible): Deep infection with major bone and tooth loss. May cause abscesses and bacteria in the bloodstream.
dentales_riesgo_desc:
â€¢ Poor dental hygiene: Main cause of plaque accumulation.
â€¢ Inadequate diet: Soft food-only diets promote tartar.
â€¢ Genetic predisposition: Breeds like Persian and Siamese are more prone.
â€¢ Older age: Cats over 5 years are at greater risk.
â€¢ Weakened immune system: Diseases like FeLV and FIV increase risk of oral infections.
dentales_signos_desc:
ğŸš¨ Warning signs:

ğŸ“Œ Bad breath (halitosis).
ğŸ“Œ Red, inflamed, or bleeding gums.
ğŸ“Œ Trouble eating or preference for soft food.
ğŸ“Œ Excessive drooling (sometimes bloody).
ğŸ“Œ Rubbing face or shaking head frequently.
ğŸ“Œ Loose or missing teeth.
ğŸ“Œ Weight loss due to reduced food intake.

ğŸ”´ Important: Cats hide pain, so owners may not notice until the disease is advanced.
dentales_prevencion: Prevention based on the catâ€™s life stage
dentales_prevencion_desc:
ğŸ± Young cats (up to 1 year):
â€¢ Introduce tooth brushing gradually.
â€¢ Balanced diet with dental kibble.
â€¢ Annual vet check-up for dental monitoring.

ğŸˆ Adult cats (1â€“7 years):
â€¢ Regular tooth brushing (at least 3 times a week).
â€¢ Proper diet with dental kibble and dental treats.
â€¢ Veterinary check-ups every 6â€“12 months.

ğŸˆâ€â¬› Senior cats (>7 years):
â€¢ Professional dental cleanings when needed.
â€¢ Water additives or dental gels as support.
â€¢ Frequent health checks to detect oral issues early.

carcinoma_que_es: âš ï¸ What is Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Cats?
carcinoma_que_es_desc: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is an aggressive type of tumor in cats that, despite available treatments, has a severe prognosis because it is generally not detected until it is in an advanced stage. This form of cancer primarily affects older cats and is one of the leading causes of tumors on the skin, nose, and mouth in felines.
factores_riesgo_desc:
â­ Sun exposure: Ultraviolet radiation is one of the main factors that can cause this type of cancer.

â­ Lack of pigmentation: Cats with white skin or areas without pigment are more vulnerable.

â­ Sparse fur: Cats with little hair are more exposed to sun damage in uncovered areas.

â­ Papillomavirus: Infection with this virus can increase the risk.

â­ Weak immune system: Immunosuppression or chronic skin conditions can make cats more susceptible.
zonas_afectadas_desc:
â­ Ears: The ear flaps are the most commonly affected areas, representing 72% of cases.

â­ Around the eyes: This area is vulnerable and constitutes 22% of cases.

â­ Snout: The bridge of the nose can also be affected, though less frequently (6% of cases).
tipos_cce_desc:
â­ Oral SCC: This type of carcinoma affects the cat's mouth, making it difficult for them to eat and causing visible discomfort.

â­ Ocular SCC: Affects the cat's eyes, potentially causing inflammation, irritation, or vision changes.

â­ **Cutaneous SCC (cSCC): This carcinoma develops on the skin, especially in areas with little hair coverage, such as ears, nose, and around the eyes.
prevencion_desc: Protecting your cat from prolonged sun exposure is one of the best ways to prevent these tumors, especially in sensitive areas like the ears and nose. Additionally, regular veterinary visits can help detect possible abnormalities early, increasing the chances of successful treatment.
dedicatoria_text:
This app was inspired by my beloved cat Kan, who left us due to this disease.

His meows, purrs, and love filled our lives. Now, his legacy lives on in the information shared here, helping to protect other felines.

Because every purr deserves to be eternal. ğŸ’™

notification_1_body: Check ears and mouth every month. A scab may be cancer.
notification_2_body: Use water fountains to encourage drinking.
notification_4_body: White ears = higher risk. Avoid sun exposure during peak hours.
notification_5_body: Balance dry food with wet food.
notification_6_body: Red or bleeding gums: dental attention needed.
notification_7_body: A wound that doesn't heal in 15 days: see a vet!
notification_10_body: White cats are more prone to Skin cancer. Check them more frequently.
notification_11_body: Neutered males are at higher risk.
notification_12_body: Dental treats help but donâ€™t replace cleaning.
notification_13_body: Nose should be clean and free of scabs. If you notice anything unusual, monitor it.
notification_15_body: Chewing on one side: possible pain.
notification_16_body: Do not place their bed in direct sunlight.
notification_17_body: Change the water twice a day.
notification_18_body: Check their mouth once a month.
notification_19_body: A growing black or pink spot: consult a vet now.
notification_20_body: Add wet food to their diet.
notification_21_body: Over 7 years old: annual dental check.
notification_22_body: Clean the mouth with cat-safe wipes.
notification_23_body: Reddish stain in litter: possible blood.
notification_24_body: No hard bones or non-specific kibbles.
notification_25_body: Frequent scratching or easy bleeding: see the vet.
notification_26_body: Place a second litter box to monitor changes.
notification_28_body: A monthly check-up can save their life.
notification_permission_desc: To enhance your experience in the app, we need permission to send you notifications.
